all right hi everyone uh so my name's
Alex and I'll be talking about building

here we go so uh I work at a company

and so with that in mind there's kind of

that was written using a different

let's go ahead and start with part one

to compile um all of that can be

a defined format oh it still works good

I'll just kind of focus on that specific
area um and so let's start by talking
about components and why they're
um so obviously there's a lot of lot to
be gain by uh using the same code in
multiple places um so it helps you
enforce being modular um picking out a
part of your app and saying this can be
used throughout the app it can be used
in different apps and that helps too
because that way you can share with the
rest of the Ember Community they can
contribute code and that helps everybody
out um so kind of isolating parts of
your app into a specific behaviors that
you can turn into components is great um
and just to kind of go over that in more

here's a little bit of illustration from

um what they have in common is they're
both they have a huge number of items in

well um and it turns out that the same
code we write for the table can also be
used for the context Chooser um so
that's great um and so we isolated this
into its own component and we even were
able to open source it so now it exists
as a library called Ember table um and
that handles large amounts of data and
it's great to have that isolated to
other people can contribute to it um and
there's other places in our app we can

there's another Library we have called

Ember server to install and watch your

great um
so it generates something like this um
there's a directory structure with an

app is populated with a bunch of great

so it's pretty easy to just run this and
now you have a place to put all your
code um it'll already serve it up um so
the app is kind of all to go and running
we can make add-ons this way so Ember
can also generate those they come with a
little bit of a different structure so
it's helpful to have a tool that just
does it via uh a single
command and that one looks a little bit
more like this there's an add-on folder
and an app folder um and everything else
ready to go so I think I'll get into
what those actually mean in just a sec
um so here's the app file structure
generated by Ember CLI um and so some
things that you see here there's an app
folder which is all of your main uh
application code um that's actually
pretty much all I want to talk about for
apps but for add-ons it's a little bit
different um so there's two folders
called app and add-on and one thing to
take note of is app is not the same as
it was in the app folder um sorry in the
in the application so now app and add-on
are both both places that you can put
Library code for your apps um and the
only difference is if you put code in
the add-on folder it'll all be part of
the add-on namespace if put code in the
app folder then when somebody installs
your library all of that code will be
merged with the application name space
um which basically means that the user
won't have to do include statements to
get at your code whereas if you put it
in the add-on folder they will have to
include from your component Library uh
specifically um so that's those are both
places that you put Library code um the
blueprints folder is a place that you
put code that will help your add-on
install so when somebody wants to use
your library um they're going to want to
install it and that should be like a a
single command and then your add-on
should do a bunch of work to set up
everything it needs to do um and so you
can put code that does that in
blueprints um it has a tests folder
which helpfully comes with a place to
put your dummy application um so there's
a tests dummy app directory that also
comes when you run that command um and
that's a great place to put your demo
application so in our old structure we
made an app folder to do that now it
goes within the tests folder which makes
a little bit more sense because that's
kind of related to testing out your app
and making sure it works um so let's go
through the problems we had before and
just kind of see how Ember add-ons
address them so first problem was Global
namespacing um before we defined
everything globally so that the host app
could access it now we Define it in one
of these two folders app and add-on and
depending on where we put it um it'll
either be in its own add-on namespace or
part of the host app namespace so the
namespacing problem uh is is a lot
better this way so add- on side we do
something like export the component and
then on the app side that's using our
library we can just import from the
component SL components um this is great
so so that's Nam spasing check uh
dependencies let's say we're in our
add-on we can specify in bower.json what
dependencies we have here some Library
um and in index.js which is kind of the
entry point for your add-on uh we have
this included hook that says uh Hey host
app I also need some library to be
installed um and the reason we have to
do this is that ember add-on are
installed by npm and they're not really
aware of bower and so to tell it to tell
your host app that it needs to have
something installed via Bower so it's
available uh you have this this hook
that lets it work um so dependencies are
are good compilation uh the old way we
had to do this or a couple ways to do
this was to have a disc folder where you
put generated files like generated
JavaScript and CSS um the new way the
host app can kind of take care of it on
its own so it can build itself it can
Minify and if you want lesser SAS you
just kind of have to include a
dependency that says hey I'm built in in
lesser SAS and then the host app can
take care of compiling that all down for
you um so compilation is a lot better
and then Discovery um in our
package.json of the uh Library app we
just have to include a keyword Ember
add-on and then that'll be indexed and
available via the site Ember add-on. so
it's much easier to search and find hey
what what what add-ons will I have that
are compatible with my new ember app um
so this takes care of pretty much all of
our concerns so we've arrived in the
promised land hooray and we can install
via just one line Ember install add-on
which is a new command um that does npm
install and generate um so this is great
um so let me move on I guess to part two
which is um what if I have a library

we've been able to keep using newer

million which is pretty impressive um
during their upgrades Embers have Val
valued reliability consistency um so
that's really nice too um and basically

from 1.0 we can get to 2.0 without

then fix it as it breaks um so what
lessons can we learn from this um have a
transition plan I think is the first one
um just having one at all avoiding
rewrites so that people don't have to
relearn how to use your app or Library
um and deprecating things before you
remove them for a couple versions um so
that's all really useful I think the
only one we're not going to follow um
for our library is deprecate them remove
because we're not at 1.0 but uh still a
useful thing to learn um so let's go so

um so let's look at a transition plan
first lesson we learned um so there we
we broke this down into three steps um
phase one we're going to try to
basically get ember table working as an
add-on while not doing any work
ourselves or as little work as possible
um so we're going to try to import
everything as a b dependency and just

then only in phase three we're going to

let's set up a new add-on Ember add-on

the first thing we're going to go do is
in that add-on the new add-on we made
we're going to go to b. Json and say we
have a dependency on Ember table and so
what we've done is we've kept the old
ember table around it's it's still you
can still install it via B like you used

our add-on that we need Ember table um
so we'll do that um
okay next thing we do is we go and make

so here we use an after install hook um
and add B package to project and so what
this is this is telling the host app is
as soon as you install this Ember table
add-on um run this code and it will
install Ember table the bower package
into your host apps b b folder um and so
this is great because because now our

.js and so if you try to use the add-on

dummy folder
um so we migrate everything from the

um and then we migrate the tests as well

we've uh we've given ourselves a way to

start migrating actual Library code um
because we have the demo app to look at

and so we only have to report the
remaining actual Library code and so
that's in phase three so we used to have
this in the source folder now it goes in
the add-on folder folder it's better to
put things in the add-on folder than the
app folder because that makes that
everything is in your apps your add-on
namespace um which kind of helps it not
be Global that way somebody who's using
your add-on can use explicit Imports and
then import things as different names or

move the source over to the add-on

app folder remember app folder and

now it's been exported in the app folder
so you can use it without importing in

what outside of what Ember add-ons knows
